instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.P3V3S0_EN: What is P3V3S0_EN? This signal enables the PP3V3_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I am working through a missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. The board appears clean.

here are the following readings
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> :1.9v LOW?
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>:  MISSING
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: 3.3v

One of the issues seems to be <SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> is only 1.9v. That line is powered by <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, which is also 1.9v.
I am missing my <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL> to turn on <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> which produces my needed <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>.
To produce <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL> I need <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> which is 0v. Now I am unsure where that gets produced or maybe my logic is just way off on this whole path I am following. Thanks for any help. Shane

edit added later//
I did replace <CHIP>U8030</CHIP>, along with <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
You cannot pursuit <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> before getting <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 79932, member: 682"]
You cannot pursuit <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> before getting <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).
[/QUOTE]
Thanks. I am assuming trigger must mean short to ground. Can I check for a drop pulse by just holding a voltage meter on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>?

can I ask another question? how come I have 1.9volts on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>? Is that even possible without <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"I am assuming trigger must mean short to ground."
More information available here:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

"how come I have 1.9volts on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>?"
Don't waste time with that...

Do not quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
Write directly into Reply box, instead of clicking Reply button.
Please, mainatain forum aesthetic.

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 79932, member: 682"]
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).
[/QUOTE]
when I trigger  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  drops fromm 3.4 volts to .3volts

May I ask what this is helping us figure out?

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
It means that SMC correctly sends out to PCH the power button signal.
Now check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses at same time.

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 80606, member: 682"]
Now check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses at same time.
[/QUOTE]
when I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> while checking voltage of <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> it stays at 0v. What is this checking for?

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Means that PCH doesn't properly react.

Check <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and the 4 RTC signals.

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 80609, member: 682"]
Check <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and the 4 RTC signals.
[/QUOTE]
3.4 and 3.2 for the first two. I am not sure what 4 signals you are referring to. I am guessing this  is to do with <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> (I did swap it prior).

I am getting 32.7khz on pin 12 of <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>

threads.title: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
RTC clock (32KHz) is provided externally to PCH.
It has internal RTC clock generator, but Apple doesn't use it...
